entry.title: Monitor CAPM service crashes using SAP BTP Alert Notification Service
entry.content:
SAP Alert Notification Service is a powerful service available on the Business Technology Platform (BTP) that helps you to monitors your applications and sends alerts when something goes wrong like an application crash so you can take immediate action.

Few things to which are required to setup beforehand:

  1. A subaccount in SAP BTP.
  2. A space created within that subaccount.
  3. Required services (capm) deployed in that space to enable monitoring.
  4. To use the Alert Notification Service, it must be subscribed within your BTP subaccount.

Now Let's create and configure Alert Notification Service

Once Create, Make sure this configuration is enabled already within the instance parameters

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


There are few terms which is very important and are explained below:

  • Events: These are the triggers specific occurrences like application crashes that the system watches for.
  • Actions: These define what should happen when a particular event is detected
  • Subscription: This is the link between events and actions. It listens for selected events and executes the configured actions when those events occur.
Flow within the Alert Notification Service:

Subscription will act as your entry point. It listens to all incoming events but only responds to the ones it’s configured for. Once a matching event is detected, it triggers the corresponding action

Configuring the Alert Notification Service:

Open the ANS dashboard, follow these steps to begin monitoring application crashes:

  1. Navigate to the "Conditions" menu.
  2. Create a new condition and set the Event Type to: app.crash
  3. This condition will help ANS identify and respond to application crash events.
Now That the Condition Is Set, Let’s Create an Action

Next, head over to the “Actions” menu from the left-hand panel in the Alert Notification Service dashboard. This is where you’ll define what should happen when your configured event like app.crash is triggered.

Select Action Type as Email and click on next

In the Actions menu, start by entering a name for your action. Then, specify the email address where you want to receive alert notifications and click on Create button

Note:  After adding your email address to the action, you’ll receive a confirmation email. Make sure to verify it before moving forward - this step is essential to start receiving alert notifications.

Now That the Action Is Set, Let’s Create a Subscription

Next, head over to the “Subscriptions” menu from the left-hand panel in the Alert Notification Service dashboard. 
Give some meaningful name and description and select your newly created action and condition as shown below:

 

 


 




 

 

 

 

 

 

Note: You might see a section called store-events in the dashboard. This was created for a different purpose, so feel free to ignore it during your setup - it’s not relevant to the current configuration.

Click Save, and just like that you’ve successfully created a subscription! Your Alert Notification Service is now ready to listen for events and take action as configured.

From now on, whenever a service crashes within the same space where your Alert Notification Service instance is set up, you’ll receive an email notification, just like the one shown below. 

 


Conclusion
Using SAP Alert Notification Service, we can now monitor services in real time. If any service crashes, we’ll receive instant alerts containing detailed information about the event.

entry.title: Mastering Total ETag in RAP , A Practical Guide.
entry.content:
In this blog I have explained the mechanism of total etag  and also differnce between  E-TAG and total etag in RAP in restful abap programming model .

Introduction :

 ETAG: the etag concept ensures that  the end user of an Odata service only changes instances with the state that is displayed on the UI .

Hence , the etag prevents changes of the BO that are not noticed by the Odata consumers .With Etag master each BO  entity can be checked independently.

TOTAL E-TAG: 

  • It enables optimistic concurrency checks durig the transition from draft to active data 
  • This total etag field on the database table is updated by the RAP runtime framework as soon as an active instance is changed  
  • Its value is compared when resuming a draft instance to ensure that the active data has not been changed after the exclusive lock has expired 

The total E-tag is used for edit-drafts, a draft that has a corresponding active instance .As soon as the exclusive lock expires and  an edit-draft is resumed , the total etag value of the draft is compared to the total ETAG value of the active instance .

The total etag is compared for all entities of BO 

Total e-tag is useful when we are changing draft data to active data .

 

why total etag? and scenario

Suppose an application is not using draft concepts ,  if it is only using e-tag then that application is also modifying the same table 

E-tag will work whenever we are loading the data in the front end , someone else changes the data  and  unknowingly  saving the data – etag will be compered 

In  order to save the data and override we use etag .

SCENARIO: 

When we start working on a draft table , we will put exclusive lock on active instance (say BOOKING ID-1)so that nobody can change the data.  

Active data base-->it will become active instance--> active instance to it will become draft instance  .

Suppose  I  have made some changes in active instance and – forgot to save it , But it will be automatically saved in draft instance – as we are working on draft 

 Chages made will be automatically saved in draft table .

As soon as we stop working – the exclusve lock will be removed from active instance (BOOKING ID-1) .

So now  the I  will come again ad start working on the draft instance which  have  Saved , again  I will put exclusive lock and make some changes in the data and save it . As soon as we save – draft instance will be converted into active instance .

What happens if we don't use total eTag? 

Suppose somebody else did some changes and those changes are not saved in draft  (the app is not using draft ) ,And we will be overwriting those changes with our changes, since we don't exactly now  whether someone eles has changed the data or not . 

Total etag will be matched automatically based on the field @Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true 

We need to match these field in behaviour definition  

The framework will update total etag field each time --> whenever we are converting draft into  active data .

Example :

1.create the table  

2.create a consumption view and provide the necessary annotation .

 3.create behaviour definition and provide total Etag and respective field.

4. create draft table .

5.create service def.

6.Create service binding.

7.OUTPUT

8.now  user 1 opens the data

9.user 2 has the same data

10.now user 1 starts editing the data 

11.suppose the user 2 trying to edit the same data--> he will get an error

13.we can see the entry in the dradft table

14.now the active draft is

15.User2 Trying to edit active draft with different value->getting error->No data found 

16.Now user2 trying to edit  with Same value->updated 

 

So total etag comes into picture !!

Conclusion:

<< Whenever we wil save the data  from active to draft instance – before saving I will compare total e-tag  value  

If it matches --> I shall save the data  

If it does not match --> i shall not save 

Whenever we change the  active data --> total etag changes each time . If nobody changes the data  ---> total etag will be matched  

If somebody changes the data--> total  etag will not be matched , we need to discrad the current draft and  we need to load the current data  

NOTE: whenever we change the draft data into active data we need total etag

 

thank you !

- Pradeep Ishwar Devadiga

entry.title: Additional Document Splitting Characteristics for Controlling
entry.content:
Document splitting in FI documents has long been a topic of discussion, mainly due to its impact on reporting. The approach depends on the specific business scenarios. For example, if reporting is required by ‘Profit Center’, then every line item in the FI document must reflect the corresponding Profit Center.

The document splitting characteristics for General Ledger accounting can be maintained at the following path:
Finance → Accounting and Financial Close → General Ledger Accounting → Business Transaction → Document Splitting → Document Splitting Characteristics for General Ledger Accounting

This configuration ensures that the document balances to zero at the splitting characteristic level—in this case, the Profit Center. For example:

Cr Vendor                 1000   EUR     PC100

Dr Expense Account 1000   EUR     PC100

Similarly:

Cr Vendor1               1000   EUR     PC100

Cr Vendor2               1000   EUR     PC200

Dr Expense Account 1000   EUR     PC100

Dr Expense Account 1000   EUR     PC200

In both scenarios, although the expense account remains the same, the amounts in the second case are distributed according to the Profit Center assigned to each vendor line item.

These are common scenarios, but there are also additional Document Splitting Characteristics designed for Controlling and for subsequent processes.

For instance, if the business requires CO reporting at the ‘Internal Order’ or ‘WBS Element’ level and wants each cost element to be posted to the respective IO or WBS, additional document splitting characteristics can be maintained for Controlling.

This is configured at:
Finance → Accounting and Financial Close → General Ledger Accounting → Business Transaction → Document Splitting → Document Splitting Characteristics for Controlling

Example:
The system can split line items in processes such as:

  • Clearing of Vendor/Customer Items
    • Cash Discount Paid
    • Cash Discount Received
    • Lost Cash Discount
  • Clearing Open Items
    • Realized Exchange Rate Differences
  • Foreign Currency Valuation for Open Items
    • Expenses/Profit from Foreign Currency Valuation
  • Flat-rate Individual Value Adjustment for Vendor/Customer Items
    • Expenses/Profit from Individual Value Adjustment

For example, in clearing open items:
A vendor invoice inherits an Internal Order (IO) from its Purchase Order (PO).

When the vendor payment is processed, the system automatically assigns this IO number to the FX realized gain account (cost element) in the payment document.

(*above screenshots are just for reference purpose and has no relation with the real-time projects)

At the time of posting the invoice, the document is split on vendor line items based on the Profit Center (the document splitting characteristic at the GL level). When posting vendor payments, the line item for the realized gain is further split based on the inherited cost object—i.e., the Internal Order from the invoice.

entry.title: Sizing Your Success: A Guide to SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
From my perspective, effective sizing is one of the most underestimated yet critical aspects of any SAP transformation. While SAP offers a standardized and well-defined architecture, every customer’s landscape, data footprint, and performance expectations are unique. This makes it essential for customers and their implementation partners to take ownership of sizing, validation, and optimization activities.

For SAP customers, partners, and technical teams navigating the shift to SAP S/4HANA and other solutions within SAP Cloud ERP Private, accurate system sizing is paramount. While SAP provides a globally consistent, standardized architecture, the responsibility for executing and validating sizing activities rests squarely with the customer and their implementation partners.

Ultimately, accurate sizing isn’t just a technical exercise; it’s a strategic enabler for stability, scalability, and long-term cost efficiency.

This guide demystifies SAP sizing, focusing on the core concepts, benefits, and practical methods within the SAP Cloud ERP Private landscape.

What is SAP Cloud ERP Private?

SAP Cloud ERP Private is a cloud-based offering that marries the control of an on-premise system with the agility and efficiency of the cloud. It guides customers toward a clean core through standardized processes and modern extensibility via SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), and in-app extensibility tools.

I think the biggest advantage of running SAP on certified cloud infrastructure that SAP Cloud ERP Private oferring adheres to is how it simplifies everything — security, compliance, and support are all built in. It lets IT teams spend less time keeping the lights on and more time driving innovation. The key, though, is being ready to fully embrace the cloud mindset to get the most out of it.

For more information please refer to Understanding the Distinct Scope of SAP Cloud ERP Private.

General SAP Sizing Overview

SAP sizing is the process of precisely determining the required hardware resources such as CPU, memory, storage, and network capacity to effectively support an SAP system based on specific business needs. It’s a blend of science, utilizing tools and calculations, and expert judgment to account for the unique context of each implementation.

Key aspects of sizing include:

  • Translating Business Requirements: Starting with user counts, transaction volumes, data growth, and performance expectations.
  • Hardware Determination: Calculating the required compute, memory, and storage.
  • Iterative Process: Sizing isn't a one-time event. It must be revisited as the business and technology evolve. This is because sizing relies on assumptions and approximations about future usage, and it must balance optimal performance with cost management.
  • Data Quality is Critical: The accuracy of the sizing results is heavily dependent on the quality of the validated usage data and sizing assumptions provided by customers and partners.

SAP Cloud ERP Private Sizing Strategy

Sizing for SAP Cloud ERP Private is a vital step to ensure your infrastructure efficiently supports your SAP workloads. SAP offers two primary models:

  1. Standard Sizing: A simplified, consumption-based model using predefined T-shirt size service bundles (e.g., XXS to 4XL), which provides a baseline scope with a minimal sizing effort.
  2. Tailored Sizing: A more granular, customized approach for complex landscapes, offering greater flexibility based on detailed requirements.

Key Sizing Steps

A structured approach to sizing includes:

  • Define the Scope: Identify the SAP applications (e.g., SAP S/4HANA, SAP BW/4HANA) and specific modules, determine transaction workloads, and define usage (e.g., Production, QA).
  • Collect Baseline Data: Use tools like the SAP Quick Sizer for new systems or EarlyWatch Reports and historical data (ST03N / ST06) for existing ones. For migrations, the SAP Readiness Check is essential.
  • Use SAP Sizing Tools: Leverage tools like Quick Sizer (greenfield) or specific sizing reports like /SDF/HDB_SIZING (brownfield) to get technical resource estimates.
  • Incorporate Growth & Buffer: Always plan for projected growth (3–5 years) and add a buffer (typically 10–25%) for peak loads and future needs.
  • Validate with Experts: Review and validate sizing with SAP experts, potentially via a "Size to Scale" engagement through SAP Premium Engagement.

Standard Sizing: The T-Shirt Model

The Standard approach maps your business needs to a predefined, T-shirt-sized model.

Full User Equivalent (FUE)

The starting point for Standard sizing is calculating the Full User Equivalent (FUE). An FUE reflects the average workload of a typical user, with different user types weighted accordingly:

User Type

FUE Weight

Developer Access

0.50

Advanced Use

1

Core Use

5

Self-Service Use

30

The final FUE count determines the required hardware package.

Example Sizing Tiers (SAP S/4HANA Illustration)*

T-Shirt Size

FUE Range

Production DB RAM (Example)

XXS

60 to 135

256 GB

XS

136 to 550

256 GB

S

551 to 1,000

512 GB

L

2,001 to 4,000

2,048 GB

*This for illustration only. Always refer to the SAP Service Description Guide for the latest metrics.

Strategies in Deployment Models

Model

Sizing Method

Primary Tool(s)

Key Action

Greenfield (new implementation)

Use projected user and transaction volumes

SAP Quick Sizer (SAP HANA-based)

The tool outputs can then mapped to FUE and a corresponding T-shirt size.

Brownfield (system conversion)

Analyze historical data and current system usage

/SDF/HDB_SIZING report (SAP Note 1872170)

Perform data archiving and cleanup first, then run the report to estimate SAP HANA memory and map to the closest T-shirt size.

Refer to the Key Resources section for tools and reports that will help you identify the right option for your scope.

Tailored Sizing: Customization for Complexity

The Tailored Option provides granular control and customized hardware specifications. This model combines standard tools with deep expert analysis, allowing more precise control over application server sizing and high-availability (HA)/disaster-recovery (DR) configurations.

Tailored Sizing Approaches

Model

Sizing Method

Primary Tool(s)

Key Action

Greenfield

Based on business assumptions and projected volumes

SAP Quick Sizer (SAP HANA-based)

Generates hardware-independent recommendations (SAPS, memory, disk).

Brownfield

Based on analysis of historical data and system usage

/SDF/HDB_SIZING report, SAP Readiness Check, EWA

Housekeeping is critical. Report output is refined by an SAP expert to account for custom code and specific usage.

In a tailored environment, the strategy shifts to "right-sizing" for current needs. This means leveraging the cloud’s elasticity to scale up or down instead of provisioning for multi-year growth upfront, which is the case for traditional on-premise models.

Refer to the Key Resources section for tools and reports that will help you identify the right option for your scope.

“Size to Scale” and Technical Assessment

The SAP Cloud ERP Private Technical Assessment is a mandatory, comprehensive evaluation designed to analyze and document the technical requirements, architecture, and sizing needs.

SAP Expert Sizing Engagement

For complex, large, or unusual landscapes, engaging an SAP expert is highly recommended. The "Size to Scale" is the expert sizing service from SAP offered via SAP Premium Engagements (MaxAttention or ActiveAttention). It provides a deep-dive, tailored sizing service.

When is "Size to Scale" required?

SAP proactively escalates an implementation for expert review if:

  • Initial analysis indicates a SAP HANA DB Requirement > 4 TiB.
  • A large amount of custom code is being migrated.
  • There are plans to consolidate multiple ERP solutions or significant new functionality (e.g., embedded EWM/TM).

SAP Sizing & Technical Assessment Engagement Flow

The sizing process is a multi-step flow involving different teams:

  1. Initiation & Scoping: Define objectives and scope with Customer, SAP Account Executives, and SAP Cloud Architecture & Advisory (CAA).
  2. Data Collection & Pre-Assessment: Customer and partner run sizing reports (e.g., /SDF/HDB_SIZING, SAP Readiness Check) and collect historical performance data.
  3. Sizing Analysis: The SAP CAA team analyzes data, maps it to infrastructure (T-shirt or tailored specs), and applies the necessary growth buffer.
  4. Technical Assessment Review & Validation: Finalized sizing assumptions are reviewed, aligned on HA/DR/network, documented in the Technical Assessment Report, and signed off by the customer.
  5. Handover to Delivery: The infrastructure is provisioned as per the agreed specifications.

Monitoring and Reporting in Cloud ERP, Private

After provisioning, continuous monitoring is key to validating the sizing and ensuring performance. This is managed through core services provided as part of the SAP Cloud ERP Private offering:

  • Capacity Management: This ongoing process ensures the environment meets performance and availability requirements by monitoring utilization, forecasting demand, and dynamically adjusting resource allocation.
  • Problem Management: This function identifies, analyzes, and resolves capacity and performance issues. It links directly back to sizing by investigating if initial assumptions were inaccurate and recommending a necessary resizing or optimization.
  • Performance Benchmarking (Enhanced Operations Services for Large Enterprises – EOS LE): A jointly defined service that measures selected business transactions over time, helping to identify performance trends and proactively mitigate future issues. 

    For more information on EOS LE please refer to SAP Cloud ERP, Private Service Description site.

By diligently performing and validating your sizing assumptions, your organization can ensure that your SAP S/4HANA journey in SAP Cloud ERP Private is built on a foundation of optimal performance, scalability, and cost efficiency.

Greenfield vs. Brownfield: Sizing Strategies for SAP S/4HANA Success

When moving to SAP S/4HANA, especially within the SAP Cloud ERP Private environment, the path you choose dictates your sizing strategy. Do you start fresh (greenfield) or convert an existing system (brownfield)?

While both methods rely on core SAP sizing tools, the inputs, assumptions, and required infrastructure for CPU, RAM, and storage diverge significantly. Understanding these differences is crucial for accurate provisioning and avoiding costly over- or under-sizing.

Sizing Approaches: Greenfield vs. Brownfield at a Glance

Aspect

Greenfield Sizing

Brownfield Sizing

Data Volume

New system, usually reduced data footprint (selective migration)

Full data migration — larger existing database size (full history)

Sizing Approach

Based on projected business requirements (users, transactions, volumes)

Based on existing system usage and historical performance metrics

Primary Tools

SAP Quick Sizer, business blueprints

SAP HANA sizing reports (e.g., /SDF/HDB_SIZING)

Custom Code

Limited or redesigned; minimal impact on sizing

Custom code retained; requires analysis (Custom Code Analyzer) as it may increase RAM/CPU requirements

Sizing Buffer

Add buffer for uncertainties in new processes (e.g., 20–30%)

Add buffer for custom code, transition load, and compatibility layers (e.g., 15%)


Greenfield Sizing: Building from the Blueprint

Use Case: A new SAP S/4HANA system deployment, often involving redefined, standardized business processes and a selective data migration.

Key Considerations:

  • Reliance on SAP Quick Sizer: Since no historical data exists, sizing is purely business-driven. You input future metrics like the number of users by type, sales order volumes, and financial transaction counts. The Quick Sizer outputs estimates for SAP HANA memory, CPU cores, and disk sizes.
  • Reduced Data Footprint: Greenfield often means selective data migration (e.g., only the last 2–3 years of transactional history). This results in a smaller initial database, lower storage requirements, and reduced initial RAM needs.
  • Cleaner Architecture: With fewer customizations and a focus on standard SAP S/4HANA processes, sizing for application performance is more predictable.
  • Add a Growth Buffer: As with any new implementation, add a significant buffer (typically ~20–30%) to account for future data growth, unforeseen business process changes, or new functionality adoption.

Brownfield Sizing: Converting the Past to the Future

Use Case: Converting an existing SAP ECC or SAP S/4HANA system to the private cloud, retaining existing processes and full data history.

Key Considerations:

  • Historical Data Analysis is Key: Sizing is usage-based. You must analyze the current system's historical performance to get an accurate estimate.
    • Workload Analysis: Use ST03N (workload analysis) and ST06 (system resources) data, and EarlyWatch Reports to understand CPU and memory utilization patterns.
    • Data Archiving is Best Practice: To optimize your sizing, archive and clean up unnecessary data before running the sizing reports.
  • The Crucial Sizing Report: The primary tool is the SAP HANA Sizing Report (/SDF/HDB_SIZING), detailed in SAP Note 1872170. This report runs on your existing system to analyze current database size, compression factors, and transaction volumes, providing a precise estimate of the required SAP HANA memory.
  • Accounting for Custom Code: Custom programs and reports (often numerous in an SAP ECC system) require assessment. The Custom Code Analyzer helps evaluate their impact, as unoptimized custom code can significantly increase required CPU and RAM.
  • Include Conversion Load: Be aware that the migration itself requires a temporary sizing uplift for staging, code remediation, and data transformation activities.

Example Sizing Comparison Snapshot

Metric

Greenfield

Brownfield

Initial DB Size

∼500 GB (selected)

1.5 TB (full)

SAP HANA Memory Estimate

∼256 GB

∼768 GB

CPU Cores

∼16–20 cores

∼36–40 cores

 

Key Recommendations and Next Steps

Sizing is a collective responsibility. While SAP and its certified partners provide the tools and expertise, customers must provide validated data and usage assumptions.

Always Validate:

  • Consult Experts: Always validate your sizing results—especially for complex brownfield conversions—with SAP CAA or a "Size to Scale" expert engagement through SAP Premium Engagement.
  • Compare Results: If you are unsure, run both the Quick Sizer (for a clean slate estimate) and the sizing reports (for historical usage) and compare the outcomes.
  • Documentation is Key: All sizing assumptions, data sources, and final resource estimates must be formally documented in the Technical Assessment Report as part of your SAP Cloud ERP Private onboarding.

Essential Resources:

By paying close attention to these greenfield and brownfield distinctions, you ensure your SAP S/4HANA landscape in SAP Cloud ERP Private is built on the right foundation for performance and scalability from day one.

Key Resources for SAP Sizing & Technical Readiness

Proper sizing and technical readiness are critical when planning, deploying, or migrating SAP solutions. Whether moving to SAP S/4HANA, SAP BW/4HANA, SAP Datasphere, or deploying on cloud platforms, the right references ensure smooth execution.

SAP Sizing Resources

  • SAP Sizing toolset
  • SAP Service Description Guide – scope of SAP services
  • SAP Note 1872170 – ABAP on SAP HANA sizing (SAP S/4HANA, Suite on SAP HANA)
  • SAP Note 2296290 – SAP BW/4HANA sizing

entry.title: CREATING CAPM APPLICATION WITH NODE.JS BY USING S/4 HANA DATABASE - Part 2
entry.content:
Hello Buddies!!

Have you Subscribed to all our pre-requisites for the development?

No 😐!!!

Don't worry let's set it up. Follow the link below!!

https://community.sap.com/t5/welcome-corner-blog-posts/creating-capm-application-with-node-js-by-using-s-4-hana-database/ba-p/14208638

Welcome to next episode of CREATING CAPM APPLICATION WITH NODE.JS BY USING S/4 HANA DATABASE.

In this Episode Lets Create an Capm Application by Using a Template, So that deployment configurations will be added automatically without manual errors.

Step1: Click on the light = icon and select Project from Template > Cap Project. 

 

Step2: Click on next and Fill the details like Project name, Runtime environment. I named my project as zcapm_hanadb.

 

 

 

 

Click on Finish. Hurray our app gets generated in few seconds.

Note: Check whether you are subscribed to Hana cloud, which is already there in prerequisites blog, We have also created a instance for that.

Now make sure your Hana db instance is running.

It would take around 10 to 15 minutes to get to running status.

Now let move to SAP BAS where our application got created.

Step3: Run the application as Right click on app> Open in integrated Terminal > Enter command CDS Watch, check whether all the node modules installed or not. Enter Command

npm install

 

Step4: Next enter the command npm install -g hana-cli. In this we are installing hana cloud Command line interface where we need to push our data into.

 

Now lets work on our Project before we connect with Data Base.

Step5: In folder structure under db >data-model.cds(I have re-named it on my own interest).Name should be filename.cds 

 

Lets create our Structure, In this there should be one Unique key for every entity you have created.

Code:

 

namespace zcapm_hanadb;

entity Products {

      @title : 'Sales

Order Number'

    key id: Integer;

      @title : 'Product Name'

    name: String;

      @title : 'Price'

    price: Decimal;

      @title : 'Description'

    description: String;

      @title : 'Stock left'

    stock: Integer;
}

 

Step 6: In folder structure under srv >cat-service.cds(I have re-named it on my own interest).Name should be filename.cds

 

In this case lets declare our function calls for get and Post. Just function names are declared in this section where we are about to call them in another file.

Important Note: In defining the cds function please remember two main things,

  1. a) function(Get Call)
  2. b) action (Post Call)

Code: 

 

using zcapm_hanadb from '../db/data-model';
service CatalogService{
  entity Products as projection on zcapm_hanadb.Products;
  // get service call
 function fnCatalogGetService(name: String) returns String;
 // Post service call
action fnCreateRecord(id: Integer, name: String, price: Decimal, description:String, stock: Integer) returns String;
}

 

Step 7: In this let's create one more file under srv>cds-service.js (filename.js). 

In this file we will write our node js logic for functions we have declared in cat-service.cds.

Code: 

 

const cds = require('@sap/cds');
const {Products} = cds.entities('zcapm_hanadb');
module.exports = cds.service.impl(async function() {
   //Get call
this.on('fnCatalogGetService', async (req) => {
    const { name } = req.data;
 console.log(name, "Hello World");
// Post call
this.on('fnCreateRecord', async (req) => {
 const { id, name, price, description, stock } = req.data;
console.log("Hello World is working fine");
})
});

 

Now we have created our very basic structure of entity and has given a service name under it. In order to utilize our service lets deploy our app to S/4 Hana DB and call data from it.

Command: cds build (Find there any errors in the terminal)

command: cds watch (Run the app).

 

Note: If you found error message like in above image, then follow below steps.

  1. First enter Ctrl + C (To End the process)
  2. Click = > View > Command Palette.

 

Enter Stop port and select below one.

 

Once it is done, now again enter the cds watch. You will find the screen like below where you you can find your service.

 

Step 8:  Lets connect to our app to S/4 Hana DB.

On the top-left most corner  where our project we have opened, there when you minimize it you will find SAP HANA PROJECTS. Open them.

 

Step 9: Expand our project.

 

Step 10: Under Database Connections we can find the same project name.

Click on the Green socket symbol to bind our project to HDI container (i.e., Hana DB container).

 

  • Bind to an HDI container

 

  • Click on new service instance, it will suggest you a name(you can rename it or use it as it is)

 

 

Note: Make sure your Hana Cloud is running

 

 

On clicking on top of Database Connections click on bind all.

Next Click on Hana HD Container symbol which is on the top of project.

Mean while if you want to know what are all services got generated. Enter the command 

cf services

 

 

 

We can see our instance got reflected in sap BTP as well.

 

 

Application gets open here you can find your container with in built database with the instance we have created.

 

 

Step 11: Our service got binded in the HDI Container and let's deploy our app.

Click on the deploy icon(Rocket icon) under hana projects > your project.

 

Our deployment looks like below screen.

 

Under project > db you can observe all our hana database files got created.

 

Navigate to Hana db explorer, we see our app got deployed. Refresh the page.

 

 

 

 

As our structure is ready let’s add some data in it.

 

Step 12: Right click on your entity and select import data. Filename should be same as entity name which we have maintained in db>data-model.cds

File Data I Have Uploaded Here..

Id

name

price

Description

stock

1

Widget A

19.99

A useful widget for various tasks

100

2

Widget B

29.99

An advanced widget with additional features

50

3

Widget C

39.99

A premium widget designed for expert users

25

 

 

 

 

In Step3 it automatically reads the table from the data imported.

 

Once you click on Review, this looks like below

Click on import to database

 

 

Hurray! we don’t have any errors and it's successfully imported.

Now import it to our database table Review > Import data.

 

 

 

 

Now right click and click on Open Data. 

 

As our database is having the data now, we need to have scope to access it in our application.

Lets run the application command: cds watch --profile  hybrid.

Here after we will be using this command as will compile the runtime dependencies.

 

 

 

Error: Data is not loaded its fix it up!!!

We need to add the shared key access for the cloud foundry

Step 13: Go to btp cockpit and the service instance that we have created during deployment process, Copy it.

 

 

 

Copy the Bold letters as an Instance name and type in with the command in your app

Command: cds bind -2 <instanceName>:SharedDevKey   

 

 

 

 

Instance key also gets appeared on top of hana DB explorer.

Step 14: Next run cds watch --profile hybrid

 

Click on Products and Check your metadata is loaded or not.

 

Hurray!!! My data got loaded successfully.

In next session lets perform CRUD Operations on S/4 Hana data from SAP Fiori app as Front end...Stay Tuned😉

References:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/creating-capm-application-with-node-js-by-using-s-4-hana...

https://help.sap.com/fiori_bs2013/helpdata/en/a7/1564526ba1f25fe10000000a423f68/content.htm?no_cache...


Hope it’s helpful 😊

Thanks,
Divya MANDAVA.

entry.title: Hands-on POC with SAP AI Core
entry.content:
Artificial Intelligence is transforming how we design and extend SAP applications. Many SAP professionals are now exploring how to start working with AI inside the SAP ecosystem.
In this post, I share my hands-on experience with SAP AI Core, from my first steps to building a real Proof of Concept (POC) using low-code tools like Build Apps and BPA.

Since May, I’ve been working on a POC with SAP AI Core. At that time, I knew nothing about AI. Step by step, by practicing with the examples and samples provided by SAP, I managed to build several POCs integrating SAP AI Core with low-code tools.

The main objective is simple: accelerate development cycles and innovate with custom applications. On my roadmap, I focused on using low-code solutions like SAP Build Apps and Process Automation (BPA), while integrating AI agents to speed up processes.

Maybe in a future post I will share more details about the POCs I realized. But today, my first goal is to encourage SAP technical consultants to start this journey.

As a Senior SAP Technical Consultant, I realized that integrating an AI agent for a first POC or when consuming partner models does not require brand-new skills. But if the objective is to build and train your own model, then of course new competences are needed.

With SAP AI Core, we can easily integrate partner models (like Azure OpenAI, ChatGPT, etc.) through APIs. For most SAP technical profiles, it’s enough to follow a simple end-to-end example:

  • Select a partner model (text, image, etc.) in SAP AI Launchpad

  • Deploy it and get the URL

  • Configure the destination and start consuming your AI agent

Another option in SAP AI Launchpad is the Prompt Editor, which lets you create your own prompts on top of partner models. The key point here is security: your data is not stored in the model — it’s managed securely by SAP.

This means that integrating external AI agents is feasible without heavy upskilling.

But in my opinion, the real power of SAP AI Core comes when you train your own models. Of course, this requires upskilling in new environments and languages. The key here is HANA Vector combined with RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation). Together, they enable customers to enrich their knowledge databases and build custom agents that are more efficient, optimized, and deliver a brilliant user experience.

I believe that SAP AI Core will become a central part of the future SAP landscape, enabling faster innovation and smarter business processes.

  I’d love to hear your thoughts and experiences with SAP AI Core. Have you already built a POC or started exploring it?

entry.title: Handling Large-Scale Data Loads in SAP Cloud Integration using Snowflake Adapter
entry.content:
Integration scenarios require frequent data communication and exchange between different applications and environments. Cloud data platforms such as Snowflake provide efficient data storage and analytics. Snowflake Adapter for SAP Integration Suite is a great tool to solve your integration problems while offering a reliable and scalable capability for data-related integrations.

Snowflake Adapter in SAP CI

Snowflake Adapters can be used to implement various data solutions, a few of them are as follows:

  • Transaction Analysis for retail business : Seamlessly load high-volume transactional data into Snowflake to analyze buying behavior, sales trends, and inventory performance enabling smarter business decisions.
  • Data Archival & Historical Analysis : Adapter can be used Move large datasets into Snowflake for secure storage and long-term trend analysis without impacting operational systems.

  • Supply Chain Data : Integrate logistics, ERP, and vendor data into Snowflake to monitor supply chain efficiency.

With this, in the following sections, we will explore the key functionalities and features of the adapter in detail.

Overview

The Snowflake adapter is designed to be employed as a receiver adapter. In such a scenario, SAP Cloud Integration acts as the initiator of the calls. The adapter uses database authentication and JDBC as the transport protocol.

You can perform various CRUD operations on your Snowflake application and choose from a list of different staging storage options, such as Amazon S3, Google Cloud Storage, and Microsoft Azure.  

Below is the high-level overview of how the adapter interacting with Snowflake Application and SAP Cloud Integration.

 

Key Features

The Snowflake Adapter provides the following key features:

  • Bulk Export and Import: Supports reading files from multiple input formats like CSV, JSON, and Avro. Export data to your desired format using unload operation.
  • Snowflake Operations Support: Snowflake Adapter offers support for standard Snowflake operations (CRUD Operations).
  • Multiple options for Staging Storage: Snowflake Adapter provides various options to load data into staging storage like Amazon S3, Google Cloud Storage, or Microsoft Azure.
  • Secure Authentication: Provides secure authentication with Database Account and
    Key-Pair options.


Snowflake Adapter Integration: Practical Use Case Walkthrough:

Imagine a business scenario where 1 million records from an ERP system need to be loaded into Snowflake. If we take the straightforward route of simply fetching the data from ERP and pushing it into Snowflake, the process could drag on for several minutes. But what if we could speed things up dramatically?

By smartly combining a set of Integration Suite palettes with the Snowflake adapter, I have built a custom batch processing mechanism with which, the same operation can be completed in just a matter of seconds—delivering both speed and efficiency.

In this blog, I’ll Walk you through how to handle such high-volume data insertion with the Snowflake adapter, and we’ll also take a look at how the execution unfolds inside Snowflake itself.

Before we begin, let us assume that a table is available in Snowflake with the required schema.

CI iflow Design

Mapping Component:

Once the data is received in SAP Integration Suite; the payload will be mapped to required column headers, which are defined in the target table in Snowflake. We employ an iterating splitter to split the records into groups (defined in the Grouping field) and then insert the records in Snowflake. 

Splitter Component:

Using the Iterating Splitter, you can enable the Streaming checkbox to improve efficiency by splitting a large composite message into smaller chunks for processing. Additionally, you can enable Parallel Processing of split messages to enhance efficiency. You can specify this by providing value for Number of Concurrent Processes.

Note: You can modify the grouping, utilize parallel processing and adjust the number of concurrent processes based on your requirements.

XML Modifier Component:

XML Modifier is used to remove the XML declaration from the XML body to make XML compatible with the snowflake.



Content Modifier Component - Payload for Snowflake Adapter Insert Operation:

Content Modifier is used to store the payload to be inserted in the table. The following instructions are handy while creating the body for the payload. 

  1. Specify the table structure including datatype and columns in the <metadata> tag. 
  2. Use the <row> tag for values to be inserted. Below is the sample XML Payload for the Insert operation:
<root> 
	<metadata> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>CREATION_DATETIME</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>RECORDTYPE</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>DOC_NO</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>ITEM</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>CREATED_ON</fieldname>	 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>REF_ITEM</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>CREATED_BY</fieldname> 
	<metadata> 
	<row> 
		<CREATION_DATETIME>23012025</CREATION_DATETIME> 
		<RECORDTYPE>010101</RECORDTYPE> 
		<DOC_NO>2020202</DOC_NO> 
		<ITEM>12345</ITEM> 
		<CREATED_ON>01012025</CREATED_ON> 
		<REF_ITEM>011</REF_ITEM> 
		<CREATED_BY>AUSR</CREATED_BY> 
	</row> 
</root>

Note: metadata/row tags and datatype attributes are case-sensitive and must be in lowercase. 

Insert Using Snowflake Adapter

Switch to the Processing tab to perform the Insert.

Now the iflow designing and configuration is complete, the iflow is ready to accept the data.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Demo:

Data has been triggered from ERP and data has been inserted into snowflake.


Navigate Monitoring, you can observe that the records are inserted in Snowflake.

You can verify the same by logging into the Snowflake application. In the Monitoring section, SQL queries are created for individual records.

Earlier using a direct insertion approach, the data load into Snowflake typically required approximately 10–12 minutes. By implementing the optimized iflow design outlined above, the same volume of records is processed and inserted into the Snowflake application within 30–35 seconds, demonstrating a significant improvement in performance and efficiency.

Final Thoughts

In summary, the Snowflake adapter enables smooth, secure, and scalable integration between cloud applications and Snowflake. The successful insertion of records highlights its efficiency and reliability, positioning it as a key enabler for enterprises looking to modernize their data landscape and leverage Snowflake’s analytics capabilities.

References: https://api.sap.com/package/SnowflakeAdapterforSAPIntegrationSuite/overview

Note: The Snowflake adapter is available as part of your SAP Integration Suite license.

entry.title: Plan-then-Execute – An Architectural Pattern for Responsible Agentic AI
entry.content:
By Ron F. Del Rosario, Head of AI Security for SAP ISBN, and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

This blog is the third part in a series on agentic AI security. The first on Repudiation can be found here, and the second on Least Privilege here.

In the recently published paper Architecting Resilient LLM Agents: A Guide to Secure Plan-then-Execute Implementations, Ron and co-authors describe the Plan-then-Execute (P-t-E) pattern for agentic AI systems. In this blog, we can only give an introduction that doesn’t do the full paper justice, so we recommend you read the full guide.

The core idea is to separate strategic planning from the tactical execution of Agentic tasks. This allows better control over the behavior of the agentic systems and increases resilience against errors and misalignment. In the P-t-E pattern, the Planner establishes a plan of steps to meet the user’s instructions. Those instructions are passed one-by-one to an Executor that completes each task with the help of tools and other agents defined in the plan.

 

Plan-then-Execute

Planner and Executor

What makes the pattern “Plan-then-Execute” is that the Planner creates the workflow to complete the user’s instructions ahead of time, before any other agents, tools, data sources or input are engaged with. The Planner is more likely implemented using a Large Language Model (LLM) with strong reasoning capabilities to interpret the user’s intent and turn it into a concrete set of tasks to be executed to achieve the strategic goal. To be effective, prompts for the Planner must be engineered to produce a task list that the Executor can understand and act on. For instance, include a task description, the tool or agent to invoke, and any other context that the Executor needs to know to execute each subtask.

The Executor executes this pre-determined plan one task at the time, invoking the tools APIs or other agents to accomplish each subtask – ideally already specified by the Planner. The level of sophistication may differ by the criticality of the user scenario or agentic AI system. But in general, this means that the Executor can be implemented with a more cost-efficient, smaller, and faster LLM, or even a deterministic code component that directly executes Planner instructions.

This pattern has several key benefits. First, it has often been observed that asking an LLM to describe how it breaks down a problem increases the accuracy of its output. By forcing the Planner to think through the entire problem, the LLM is compelled into higher quality of reasoning that leads to higher success rates in completing the task.

Moreover, by preparing the plan ahead of execution, we lock in the sequence of subtasks in the workflow. This makes the execution predictable, and far more resistant to losing sight of the overall objective. Even if an individual agent misbehaves, it is not capable of altering the overall execution plan. The plan can include failure modes on error and require letting the user confirm any critical actions before transactions are committed.

Finally, the plan that the Planner produces is a clear statement of intent how the agentic system must execute the user’s intent. That creates evidence that can be used in audits, as well provide a basis to verify that the execution met the objective.

Verifier and Refiner

The P-t-E paper considers two other components to further enhance the confidence in the planning process. The first is the Verifier. The role of this architectural component is to verify the plan produced by the Planner before it is handed over to the Executor. This extends the model to Plan-Validate-Execute (P-V-E). The Verifier can be an expert in a Human in the Loop (HITL) workflow or automated with another agent or other verification method. The Verifier must have a different implementation than the Planner to avoid the Verifier making the same mistakes.

The pattern also accommodates for a Refiner, which fixes errors identified by the Verifier and updates the plan before execution. Again, this could use HITL or be automated – either as a separate model or as a function performed by the Planner.

 

Revisiting the Discount Scenario With P-t-E

It is easier to see how this works when applied to a concrete example. In part 1, we described a buyer-seller scenario with agents authorized to issue discounts. We quickly ran into Repudiation challenges since the system lacked clear workflow control, ability to establish a shared reality, or resilience to errors.

Let’s update the diagram  from part 1 with the P-t-E pattern. The Chat Agent is the interface to the Buyer and passes the user’s instruction as part of the prompt to the Planner (after sensible input sanitation) to prepare an actionable plan for the Executor.

Updated diagram of the Discount agentic AI system from part 1 with the Plan-then-Execute pattern, including a Planner and Executor providing greater resilience to misalignment and errors

Conceivably, the plan looks like this for our example scenario:

  1. Look up widgets in the catalog and check price, stock levels and delivery timelines for 15,000 widgets; use the Seller Agent with read-only privileges
  2. Return to the Buyer in case the conditions can’t be met and propose whether we should look for alternatives, or the Buyer can adjust the terms. Otherwise, present the price and delivery details for confirmation
  3. In case the buyer asks for a discount, invoke the Discount Agent; remind it to not exceed 10%
  4. Apply the discount and present the new total; repeat until the Buyer agrees or the calculated discount exceeds 10%
  5. If no agreement can be reached, escalate to a human sales representative.
  6. If agreement is reached, execute the transaction using the Seller Agent, with write access.

This breakdown of subtasks already shows several key elements that increase control over the execution of the overall objective:

  • A task description, that is, what concrete subtask we want performed
  • Which agent should fulfill that subtask
  • With what privileges the agent should execute the subtask with
  • Reminders of system prompts, that is, not to exceed the 10% discount)
  • At which critical steps the system must get confirmation from the Buyer (HITL)
  • How to fail gracefully, in this case, by escalating to a human sales representative

Once passed to the Executor it works through the task list, invoking the various agents already defined, with the least privilege to complete the task as discussed in part 2, and without their output able to influence the workflow.

The paper calls this “Automatic Planning + User-Involved Execution”. In more complex scenarios, it might be beneficial to have the Buyer validate the plan the Planner came up with in a P-V-E check (dotted arrow). This may make sense, for instance, if the agentic AI system includes 3rd-party Seller Agents of varying trust levels.

Fail Gracefully and Recover

Aside from much greater control over agent behavior, the P-t-E pattern also provides greater resilience to errors, failure and model misalignment if they still occur. Intermediation involving some kind of protocol conversion is often an effective control to fail gracefully or detect bad input or output, rather than a more impactful outcome.

The Executor can validate the output or reject it if it doesn’t meet the expected format. The Human in the Loop can verify if mistakes were made in the enforce HITL steps, before an invoice is sent. If the value of a previous step doesn’t make sense in the next subtask, that next task will likely fail, rather than execute a malicious transaction. With the right access controls in the business systems, any unauthorized discount could be rejected at the point of transaction and return an error code rather than send out an incorrect invoice. That error code could allow the Executor to retry with a correction.

 

Additional Control Points

The P-t-E pattern itself has benefits by-design. But it also allows for additional control points in implementation and operations. For instance, instead of passing in an excessive discount into the business system and hope it catches it, the Executor can check whether the discount returned by the Discount Agent meets the conditions that were set. If the discount exceeds 10%, the Executor can intervene. It can decide to instruct the Discount Agent to try again, to return the maximum allowed discount to the user, or drop into step 5 of the plan and involve a human sales representative.

As we hinted before, the plan provides an audit control point that can be paired with a comparison of the Executor logs to verify the plan’s intent was followed and executed. It provides an interface into Governance, Risk and Compliance (GRC), and thus the potential for auditable, compliant agentic AI systems. 

 

Not a Substitute for Security Basics

P-t-E is an architecture design pattern. The paper clearly states that it is not a substitute for generally accepted (AI) security practices in implementation and operations. Regardless how your agentic AI systems are designed, it is still important to:

  • Protect your data and infrastructure
  • Secure your build and deployment pipeline
  • Train with anonymized data
  • Use RAG with access controls
  • Access business systems with Business Connectors with appropriate authorizations
  • Carefully design your system prompts
  • Defend against direct prompt injections attacks, jail breaks, and system prompt leaks

SAP AI Foundation can support you in these areas for your own agentic AI projects and is the platform for SAP AI solutions.

 

Joule Agents and P-t-E

Joule agents follow a proto-pattern similar to P-t-E, using the AppRouter and Scenario Selection to determine what the agent must do. That works well for single agent scenarios.

For multi-agent – potentially multi-party – agentic AI systems, we believe that the P-t-E pattern is more appropriate. The Architecting Resilient LLM Agents: A Guide to Secure Plan-then-Execute Implementations paper mentioned earlier is under review for adoption at SAP of P-t-E as the recommended architecture pattern for agentic AI solutions.

 

Closing

In this article, we introduced the P-t-E pattern and its architectural benefits in designing secure Agentic systems. We highly recommend to the audience to read the entire research paper for further details. In the next and final part in this series, we will discuss how this pattern defends against misaligned and even deceptive model behavior.

 

More Information

  • Architecting Resilient LLM Agents: A Guide to Secure Plan-then-Execute Implementations, Ron F. Del Rosario, Klaudia Krawiecka, Christian Schroeder de Witt (ArXiv, Sep 2025)
  • “That’s Not What We Agreed!” – Repudiation and Agentic AI Threat Modeling (SAP Community)
  • Limiting Agent Autonomy – Least Privilege and Tool Access for Agentic AI Systems (SAP Community)
  • OWASP Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations (OWASP GenAI Security Project)
  • Defending Against AI Security Risks by Turning LLMs on LLMs (SAP Community)

entry.title: Re: Splitting quantities across bins
entry.content:
Hi @JackN11 

Thank you for your question.

The reason it happens is because your custom logic overrides the standard bin determination that performs capacity check. You can fix this and keep the enhancement you introduced by:

  • In your BAdI implementation, ensure to call the standard bin determination logic, this will ensure that the system still executes the automatic split routine.
  • Ensure you verify if your BAdI filter values are limited to the relevant storage types only.

The following reference will provide some details:

https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-q-a/regarding-badi-scwm-ex-core-pts-nbin-nrm-for-multiple-wt-putaway-into-same/qaq-p/427878

https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-q-a/regarding-to-badi-scwm-ex-core-pts-nbin-nrm-to-allow-mixed-storage-doesn-t/qaq-p/14158730

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Configuration and Submission of your UK VAT Return
entry.content:
In this blog post, I would like to provide a step-by-step guide on how to configure and integrate the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition with SAP S/4HANA Cloud to electronically submit the VAT Return to the tax authorities. This blog will specifically cover the setup and configuration of the VAT return for the United Kingdom (GB) – a list of some other statutory reports and countries supported by SAP Document and Reporting Compliance can be found here.

The value of the integration between SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition lies in the fact that one simply needs to setup the various steps shown below one time initially – once this is done, a single click to submit the report from SAP S/4HANA Cloud triggers the entire flow so that that the tax authority, HMRC, automatically receives the VAT return.

For the configuration/set up required for GB VAT Return, please refer to refer to this blog for details based on your SAP S/4HANA release: https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-blog-posts-by-sap/setup-communication-of-sap-document-and-reporting-compliance-cloud-edition/ba-p/14237600.

END-TO-END PROCESS

Once all the set-up and configuration has been completed, we can then run through the process of generating and submitting a GB VAT Return to HMRC

[1] Open the Run Statutory Reports FIORI app and enter the following parameters:

Reporting Entity

Report Name: GB_VAT_DCL

Reporting Year

Click

 

[2] After running and completing the activities listed, for example, Manage Tax Items, select the activity GB VAT Return Statement:

[3] Select New Run, check the defaulted selection criteria and make changes if required:

[4] After executing the report and checking the VAT return statement click on

Since the GB VAT Return process uses OAuth 2.0 and Authorization Code Flow, eliminating the need to maintain a username and password, only the VAT registration number and authorization code need to be maintained.

MAINTAINING CREDENTIALS

If you're VAT-registered, HMRC now automatically signs up new businesses for MTD for VAT unless you're exempt or have applied for exemption. Here's what you need to do:

  • Use compatible software: You must keep digital VAT records and submit VAT returns using MTD-compatible software. SAP S/4HANA provides the end-to-end process of recording your financial transactions, generating the VAT return and submitting the report electronically using the mandated API from HMRC in the correct JSON file format.
  • Sign in with your Government Gateway ID: This is your credential for accessing HMRC services. If you don’t have one, you can create a Government Gateway account: create a Government Gateway account.
  • Link your software to HMRC: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance will guide you through authorizing it to communicate with HMRC using your Government Gateway credentials.
  • To maintain your credentials for UK MTD, please go to the BTP app Manage Communication to External Parties. For UK MTD, this is your VAT registration number.

INITIAL AUTHORISATION

  • For the first submission, you will be prompted to enter your credentials in the HMRC portal. You will see a message asking if the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition is authorized to access the HMRC portal. Please select "Yes" to generate and save a token in the Integration component in BTP for 18 months.

SUBSEQUENT SUBMISSIONS

  • For 18 months after the initial authorization, you will not need to enter a username and password for submissions. The GB_VAT_DCL report will be submitted as soon as the user selects the Submit button in the Fiori app Run Statutory Reports.
  • The access tokens need to be renewed every 18 months.  If the access tokens are not valid, at the time of submission, the user will be redirected to HMRC to renew the access tokens before submission can take place

TROUBLESHOOTING:

[1] If you are transitioning from SAP Document and Reporting Compliance service to SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition and are now moving to SAP Document you can find more information here

You will need to apply all referred notes and pre-requisites of SAP note: 3386362 - UK VAT Return Submission: Implementation Overview - SAP for Me.

Further information is also available in our FAQ in the generic questions section of the Migration Guide (can be used as reference):

https://help.sap.com/docs/SLH_advanced_compliance_reporting_service/7a60944343e543a1ab99e9b2904dab09/7ce724ae2cbb454aa2b1c900bcacc0d2.html

[2] To enforce a new re-direction:

  1. Go to Communication Settings App (BTP-SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition)
  2. Search per your Identification number and click on the entry: 

      3. Click on the “X” (Delete Key) from the Authentication Setting section (you should receive a pop-up as below)

 

4. Authentication Setting Status should now appear as “Incomplete”: 

 

5. Click on + (“Add Authentication Setting”) – a pop-up will appear: 

 

6. After added, the Authentication Setting Status will appear as “Complete”: 

7. You may now resubmit your report from SAP S/4HANA Run Statutory Reports, and a redirection to HMRC should be enforced. 

        a.  Please wait few mins (˜5 mins) before resubmitting the report (this should allow any cached items to be erased).

Hopefully, this blog post gave you a detailed walkthrough of the steps needed to setup and configure the automatic electronic submission of the UK VAT Return. With this one-time setup, the users can benefit from a seamless integration between SAP S/4HANA Cloud and the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition

entry.title: Replacement of string '&3' not possible in CDS View
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

While creating a CDS View for outputting text elements, I stumbled upon an interesting behavior. To put it simply, I have the following string from an SAP text element:

'The limit for customer &1 was exceeded by &2 &3 at &4'

I apply the replace function four times to replace the string &1, &2, &3 and &4 with the following values:

value1 = '123456'
value2 = '100.00'
value3 = 'EUR'
value4 = '13.10.2015'
cast(replace(cast(replace(cast(replace(cast(replace(Text, '&1', cast(value1 as abap.char(20))) abap.char(73)), '&2', cast(value2 as abap.char(20))) as abap.char(73)), cast('&3' as abap.sstring(50)), cast(value3 as abap.char(20))) as abap.char(76)),'&4', cast(value4 as abap.char(20))) as abap.char(76)) as MessageText

This logic works fine for &1, &2 and &4, while &3 is simply not replaced, regardless of the target value that is inserted. This results in the following string:

'The limit for customer 123456 was exceeded by 100.00 &3 at 13.10.2025'

Has anyone else encountered this error, or is there a better way to output text elements in CDS?

Thanks in advance!

BR,
Lukas

entry.title: Combining Multiple Entry Comments into One Row in Concur Cognos Reports (Analysis/Intelligence)
entry.content:
Have you ever faced duplicate rows when fetching entry comments from Concur via Cognos? If so, here is the solution to fix and retrieve it in a single row.

Reason: Duplicate rows in Cognos reports on comments often arise because of the one-to-many relationship between expense reports and its comments. Since each comment is treated as a distinct record, the primary expense report is repeated for each comment linked to it.

Solution: To fetch entry comments from Concur via Cognos report without creating duplicate records, we must use a method that merges comments into a single field and here are the steps that we need to follow:

Step 1: On the SAP Concur home page click Home > Applications > Reporting > Intelligence.

Step 2: In Concur Reporting tool, click on New> Report from four horizontal lines available at top left corner.

Step 3: Select Blank template and click on Create button from the top right corner.

Step 4: Click on Select a Source+ and then click on Concur Data Warehouse.

Step 5: Click on Open.

Step 6: Expand the Expense folder on the left side and under Expense Reports > Report Header Information, select the required fields and then drag & drop it to the right side.

Step 7: Similarly, under Expense Reports folder> Entry Information, select the required fields and drag & drop it on the right side.

Step 8: On the top, click on Report> Query1 as mentioned in the screenshot.

Step 9: Click on + symbol in Data Items.

Step 10: Double click on the #Entry Key from Entry Information>Keys folder and click on OK. The Entry Key will be added to the Data Items.

 

Step 11: Click on Report> Queries.

Step 12: Drag and Drop the Query icon to the right side under Query 1.

Step 13: Query2 will be added.

Step 14: Double click on Query2.

Step 15: Double click on the Comments (under Report Entry Comments) and #Assiciated Report Entry Key (under Keys folder). The fields will be added to the Data Items.

Step 16: Click on Report> Page1.

Step 17: Under Toolbox icon, double click on Repeater icon.

Step 18: Make sure the Query2 is selected under Query Name and Click OK.

Step 19: The Repeater column is added at the right end of the table.

Under Date Items icon drag and drop the Comment under Query2 to the Repeater column available on the right side.

Step 20: Click on Comments under Repeater Column and select the three vertical dots from the options and then select Mater Detail Relationships.

Step 21: Click on New Link. Make sure the link is connected as mentioned in the screenshot. Click OK

Step 22: Click on Repeater field. Enter ‘Entry Comments’ in the text box and click OK

Step 23: Click on lock icon to unlock

Step 24: From the Toolbox icon. Drag and drop the Text Item to the comment field. Enter , (comma and space) in the Text window and then click OK.

Step 25: Click Lock icon to lock the report.

Step 26: Click on Report> Page1

Step 27: Select Employee and Report Name columns and then click on Group icon as shown in the screenshot.

Step 28: Click on Save icon to save the report. Click on Run button to retrieve the data and multiple comments entered for an expense entry will be appearing in a single row with comma in the output file.

entry.title: Re: Fiori Launchpad for Sourcing and Procurement
entry.content:
Hello @JackN11

Thank you for your question.

Just to summarise, there is no single Track Down Payment app in the public cloud. You can instead use a combination of Finance and Procurement apps for that. You can approach by:

  • Displaying Supplier Down Payment Requests: track down payment requests linked to POs.
  • Manage Supplier Line Items: here you can view down payment postings.
  • Monitor Purchase Order Items: this helps you to see down payment and payment status at PO level.
  • Display Supplier Balances:  You can verify those balances including your down payments.

 Have a look at the following links for more guidance.  https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/6fb104f9b69241118a1ca76f7d4550bf.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/0627d253913e4608e10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US

Whilst doing that, ensure that your scope item for supplier down payments is active and that your PO payment terms contain the down payment indicator.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP, Mitsubishi Electric and IBM will co-host the InnerSource Summit - Join us on November 13!
entry.content:
InnerSource is the practice of applying Open Source methodologies, culture and best practices to in-house software development.

Although still unknown by many, the practice counts with a big community in the tech industry, supported by the InnerSource Commons foundation. How big? So big that this year the InnerSource Summit, which is the main event for this topic, will be hosted by three companies, across three different continents, providing nearly 24 hours of content!

In this post we will talk about what InnerSource is, where to find its community, the largest event for the topic, and how to be part of it!

TL;DR: Join SAP, Mitsubishi Electric, and/or IBM in 🇩🇪 Berlin, 🇯🇵 Yokohama, 🇺🇸 New York or 🌐 online on 🗓️ November 13 for the InnerSource Summit 2025.

What is InnerSource?

Have you ever had a great experience with an open source project? I mean, not just a great experience using what the project delivers, but something that goes beyond that, like find a welcoming invite and joining the project's community, or easily finding you could contribute and sending a pull request that got accepted.

Imagine if we could replicate that experience inside our companies!

This is what InnerSource is, making closed-source projects great, by applying in them the learnings from successful open source projects, and steering the company culture towards openness, transparency and collaboration.

Sounds simple, right? Well, yeah, the idea is simple, but making open source and InnerSource projects great is more than just having the source code in a git repository somewhere. That's why the practice has a name and also a community around it to document and share the best practices.

Who's doing InnerSource?

A lot of people still haven't heard about InnerSource and they would probably be surprised by how mature the topic is. I mean, sure, many companies are still on their early days in adopting the practice, it is a marathon, not a sprint. Nevertheless, InnerSource Commons, a large cross-industry community for the topic, was established already 10 years ago (which we are celebrating in our event, by the way), and incorporated as a foundation in 2020.

Among the companies who already talked publicly about InnerSource you will find big names, such as Bosch, BBC, IBM, PayPal and, of course SAP.

SAP is an active member of the InnerSource (Commons) community, and that's one of the reasons why we are co-hosting the InnerSource Summit in Berlin this year!

The InnerSource Summit

The InnerSource summit is an yearly (sometimes bi-yearly) event organized by InnerSource Commons since as early as 2016, where experts and interested parties come together to share their knowledge, learn from each other, recharge their InnerSource batteries and expand their network.

This year we will have the event onsite for the first time since 2019 (as it has been running virtually since 2020), and it is coming back with bang!

To celebrate the 10th year of InnerSource Commons, the event will take place not only online, but it will follow the sun onsite across three different locations (on three different continents!), and will be co-hosted by three different companies!

It will start in 🇯🇵 Yokohama, hosted by Mistsubishi Electric, which will be followed by SAP hosting it in 🇩🇪Berlin, and finally it will end in 🇺🇸 New York, hosted by IBM.

In our leg, Peter Giese, Director of the SAP Open Source Program Office, will get things started with the keynote "From Code to Culture: Scaling Collaboration with InnerSource", and will be followed by fifteen speakers with topics including the state of InnerSource in the industry, open communication, adoption stories, implementation of InnerSource analytics, usage of AI for cross-team collaboration, and more!

Join us!

Did I catch your interest in learning more about InnerSource ad meeting its community? Then join us, onsite or online!

In special, I'll be thrilled to meet you in our onsite leg of the event in 🇩🇪Berlin at the SAP Office.

Visit the InnerSource Summit 2025 website for the full event agenda and registration links.

Learn more about InnerSource

  • https://innersourcecommons.org
  • Blog Post Establishing InnerSource at SAP
  • Blog Post Cultivating InnerSource at SAP
  • FOSS Backstage 2024 - Presentation Driving the InnerSource Program at SAP

entry.title: Migrating SAP Profile and Microservices to SAP BTP Kyma
entry.content:
Over the past months, our SAP Community Portal team took on one of the most ambitious infrastructure projects in recent years: migrating the SAP Profile and the supporting microservices of the SAP Community Platform from SAP BTP Neo and SAP Converged Cloud (Kubernikus) to SAP BTP Kyma Runtime.

This was more than a technical migration: We wanted to strengthen our platform for the long term, simplify operations, and empower the team with modern cloud-native tools and practices.

Motivation

Over time, our platform had grown across multiple environments — SAP BTP Neo and SAP Converged Cloud (Kubernikus) — each with its own operational footprint and limitations. To continue evolving the SAP Community and SAP Profile, we needed a foundation that was both modern and sustainable.

Our goals were clear:

  • Increase development speed and efficiency through improved tooling, automation, and infrastructure

  • Reduce operational costs and complexity by adopting SaaS-managed databases and retiring legacy Neo Global Accounts

  • Address security and maintenance risks tied to the aging Kubernikus environment

Solution

To achieve this, we migrated a suite of critical services, including the Avatar Service, Subscription Service, Session Service, and Khoros Firehose Integration, to SAP BTP Kyma Runtime.
We also switched to SAP BTP PostgreSQL, introduced NATS for messaging, and integrated everything into Hyperspace build pipelines for streamlined CI/CD.

The transition required close collaboration between development, operations, and architecture teams. Careful planning, extensive testing, and phased rollouts helped ensure that users experienced no disruptions — even as we moved the foundation of the platform beneath their feet.

SAP runs SAP

This migration is part of SAP’s broader transformation journey - applying our own cloud technologies internally and learning from the experience. By moving our services to SAP BTP Kyma, we’re contributing to SAP’s “Run SAP on SAP” strategy and setting the stage for continued innovation in the years ahead.

To achieve this, we migrated a suite of critical services, including the Avatar Service, Subscription Service, Session Service, and Khoros Firehose Integration to SAP BTP Kyma Runtime. We also switched to BTP PostgreSQL, introduced NATS for messaging, and integrated everything into Hyperspace build pipelines for streamlined CI/CD.

Acknowledgments
Special thanks to @weckerle, @aliona_boltromeyuk, @hyerimm, @irene-glaz, @erikdietz284 as well as @MirkoFriedrich and @yaniv for leading this effort and to all consultants who contributed their expertise throughout the migration.

entry.title: Standard ALV Line Selection instead of Checkbox in SAP
entry.content:
In many SAP reports, we build ALV outputs and allow the user to select certain rows for further processing.
A common approach is to add a custom checkbox column in the field catalog and capture user-selected rows.

But did you know?
👉ALV itself provides a built-in line selection mechanism — no need for extra checkbox fields.
This makes your report look cleaner and behave more like standard SAP transactions (e.g., ME2N, ME23N).

In this post, I’ll share how to enable row selection both in OOPs ALV (CL_GUI_ALV_GRID) and Classical ALV (REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY), along with the benefits.


OOPs ALV with Container (CL_GUI_ALV_GRID):


Enable Line Selection

DATA: ls_layout TYPE lvc_s_layo.

ls_layout-sel_mode = 'A'.   " A = Multiple

CALL METHOD gr_alvgrid->set_table_for_first_display
  EXPORTING
    is_layout       = ls_layout
  CHANGING
    it_outtab       = gt_final
    it_fieldcatalog = gt_fcat.

 Fetch Selected Rows

DATA: lt_rows TYPE lvc_t_row,
      ls_row  TYPE lvc_s_row,
      lv_index TYPE sy-tabix.

CALL METHOD gr_alvgrid->get_selected_rows
  IMPORTING
    et_index_rows = lt_rows.   " selected row indices

LOOP AT lt_rows INTO ls_row.
  lv_index = ls_row-index.         " Index in GT_FINAL
  READ TABLE gt_final INDEX lv_index INTO DATA(ls_final).
  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    " ---> Do your processing with ls_final
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.



Classical ALV (REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY)

Define Layout & Call ALV

DATA: ls_layout TYPE slis_layout_alv.
ls_layout-sel_mode = 'A'.  " A = Multiple

CALL FUNCTION 'REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY'
  EXPORTING
    i_callback_program      = sy-repid
    i_callback_user_command = 'USER_COMMAND'
    is_layout               = ls_layout
    it_fieldcat             = gt_fcat
  TABLES
    t_outtab                = gt_final.

 Handle User Command

FORM user_command USING r_ucomm     LIKE sy-ucomm
                        rs_selfield TYPE slis_selfield.

  DATA: lt_rows TYPE slis_t_row,
        ls_row  TYPE slis_row,
        ls_final TYPE your_table_type,
        lr_grid TYPE REF TO cl_gui_alv_grid.

  CASE r_ucomm.

    WHEN 'SUBMIT'.  " Custom button
      CALL FUNCTION 'GET_GLOBALS_FROM_SLVC_FULLSCR'
        IMPORTING e_grid = lr_grid.

      CALL METHOD lr_grid->get_selected_rows
        IMPORTING et_index_rows = lt_rows.

      LOOP AT lt_rows INTO ls_row.
        READ TABLE gt_final INDEX ls_row-index INTO ls_final.
        IF sy-subrc = 0.
          " -> process ls_final
        ENDIF.
      ENDLOOP.
  ENDCASE.
ENDFORM.

 
Advantages over Checkbox Selection

  1. Cleaner UI – No need to add an extra checkbox column.

  2. Standard SAP Behavior – Works like ME2N/ME23N where row selection is natural.

  3. Multiple Modes – Single row, multiple row, column, or cell selection possible.

  4. Event Driven – Double-click events can directly trigger detailed processing.

  5. Less Code – No need to manage an extra field (X/space) for selection.

 

Conclusion

Whenever you design ALV reports, prefer standard line selection instead of custom checkbox fields.
It not only reduces development effort but also gives your users a familiar SAP standard look and feel.

Let me know if anyone tries this or if there's a better way to optimise it. I hope this helps! Let me know your thoughts or if you have any questions.

Thanks,

Akshay Anil   Linkedin Profile
Technical Consultant, SAP ABAP | BTP | Fiori | Ui5

#ABAP #SAP #SAPABAP #ABAPTips #SelectionScreen #SAPGUI #UIDesign #SAPCommunity
